titleInfo.title: 19-605 Cox Mound Site 5AN19, Anderson County, Tennessee. [General view of site prior to excavation]

mods.abstract: This land upon which the mound is constructed is part of the old river bank, the east one, Clinch River. The land has been under cultivation for nearly one hundred years. One old inhabitant told me he cut wheat on part of the land fifty-five years ago. The land is subjected to periods of inundation whenever the river reaches flood stage, consequently, the mound showed some evidence of river deposits. The land had already been planted in corn before work began so the mound was staked conservatively (60x60) but after work began ten feet of additional area was added to the north and designated as prime to the numbers. Before completion, it might be necessary to add an additional ten feet to the south to further trace Feature 1. The mound shows numerous layers of mussel shell especially a the lowest level (old village site?) where it attains a thickness of ten inches in spots. Most of the pottery and animal bones come from two levels, the first 22" - 24" below this level. Burials have been recovered from both of these levels, none in between them.

name.namePart: Frank H. McClung Museum of Natural History and Culture
